text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred in February 18 in history.
1248 - Imperial forces under Frederick II were defeated at Parma in Italy.
1455 - Fra Angelico (Guido di Pietro), Dominican Friar and Italian painter of many religious works, died. Famed for his "Last Judgement" at Orvieto as well as his contemplative frescoes in Florence.
1478 - George, Duke of Clarence, convicted of treason against his brother Edward IV, was murdered in the Tower of London. He was drowned in a wine butt.

1516 - Mary I, Queen of England, born, the daughter of Henry VIII and his first wife Catherine of Aragon. Queen from 1553, she became known as "Bloody Mary" after her campaign against Protestants in England.
1546 - Martin Luther, German Augustinian Friar and leader of the 16th century Protestant reformation, died.

1564 - Michelangelo Buonarotti, Italian painter, sculptor and architect, died. Described as the most brilliant representative of the Italian Renaissance,he was famed for his work on the Sistine Chapel, his painting of "The Last Judgement" and his statue of "David".
1745 - Count Alessandro Volta, Italian physicist, born. He gave his name to a unit of electricity and invented the electric battery in 1800.
1861 - In Italy, the first parliament met and proclaimed Victor Emmanuel as King.
1865 - After being besieged, the Unionist fleet took the town of Charleston in South Carolina in the U.S. Civil War.
1884 - British General Charles Gordon arrived at Khartoum in the Sudan in an attempt to end to the rebellion by the Mahdi.
1900 - The battle of Paardeberg began in the second Boer War. The Boers under Piet Cronje eventually surrendered (Feb 27) under the weight of British artillery led by Lord Roberts.
1915 - In World War One, Germany began a blockade of England using submarines.
1916 - In Cameroon, the last German soldiers surrendered to the Allies thus ending German control of the colony.
1918 - German Army launched an offensive against Russia and within a week had occupied the Baltic States.
1919 - Jack Palance, U.S. film actor, born as Walter Palahnuik.
1932 - Milos Forman, U.S. film director, born in Czechoslovakia. His film "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" (1975) won five Oscars.
1944 - In World War Two, RAF Mosquitoes bombed Amiens prison in France, allowing 100 prisoners to escape.
1951 - In Vietnam, Prime Minister Tran Van Huu announced the formation of a new government.
1951 - In Nepal, a new Council of Ministers was sworn in thus ending century-old Rana domination and starting a new democracy.
1954 - John Travolta, U.S. film actor, born. Star of "Saturday Night Fever", "Grease" and "Pulp Fiction".
1960 - Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru and Uruguay agreed to set up a Latin American Free Trade Association.
1965 - Gambia became an independent state within the Commonwealth.
1967 - Robert Oppenheimer, U.S. physicist and father of the atomic bomb, died.
1980 - In Canada, Pierre Trudeau, leader of the Liberal Party, returned to office as prime minister.

1981 - U.S. President Reagan's first budget proposed the largest tax cuts and spending curbs ever for an administration, including $90,000 million dollars increase in defence spending over four years.
1991 - An IRA bomb in exploded in London's Victoria Railway station, killing one and injuring at least 40 people.
1994 - Delegates from 130 countries agreed at a United Nations conference that there must be new cuts in greenhouse gas emissions to halt if global warming.
1996 - An IRA explosion ripped apart a bus in Londons, killing one person and injuring nine others.
